review.title: Three new sensitivity analysis methods for influence diagrams
review.abstract: Performing sensitivity analysis for influence diagrams using the decision circuit framework is particularly convenient, since the partial derivatives with respect to every parameter are readily available [Bhattacharjya and Shachter, 2007; 2008]. In this paper we present three non-linear sensitivity analysis methods that utilize this partial derivative information and therefore do not require re-evaluating the decision situation multiple times. Specifically, we show how to efficiently compare strategies in decision situations, perform sensitivity to risk aversion and compute the value of perfect hedging [Seyller, 2008].

metadata.title: Three new sensitivity analysis methods for influence diagrams

sections.text: Performing sensitivity analyses for influence charts using the decision-making framework is particularly convenient as the partial derivatives are readily available for each parameter [Bhattacharjya and Shachter, 2007; 2008]. In this paper, we present three non-linear sensitivity analysis methods that use this partial derivative information and therefore do not require repeated re-evaluation of the decision situation. In particular, we show how strategies can be efficiently compared in decision-making situations, sensitivity to risk aversion can be exercised and the value of perfect hedging can be calculated [Seyller, 2008].

sections.heading: 2.3 Sensitivity Analysis in Influence Diagrams
sections.text: Howard [1968] uses terminology from the literature on systems analysis to classify sensitivity analysis into two categories. He refers to the variation of a parameter and the calculation of the specific equivalent of a fixed strategy as open loop analysis; if the strategy is allowed to vary by re-evaluating the decision situation, it is a closed loop analysis. Closed loop results require a re-evaluation of the influence diagram, which can be done as efficiently as possible using decision circuits. Nevertheless, open loop DM results can provide important insights using information already computed in the original circuit. Preparations in sensitivity analysis in influence diagrams include different parameters such as conditional probabilities and finding intervals over which the current strategy remains optimal [Nielsen and Jensen, 2003; Bhattacharjya and Shachter, 2008].

sections.heading: 2.4 The Value of Perfect Hedging
sections.text: Seyller [2008] writes,... "in the late 17th century Japan, in Dojima, near Osaka, a futures market for rice was developed... It was the first recorded case in which such a market was created." Seyller defines the value of hedging from a decision-analytical perspective, and it is this approach that we use in this paper. In a decision situation, hedging occurs through a deal that is already relevant to us. Suppose we have a coin toss deal in which we receive $50 for heads or $50 for tails. Now, consider another deal in which the payouts are reversed, i.e. we pay for heads and receive for tails. If we believe that heads and tails are equally likely, then these two deals have identical value when viewed separately. In addition, we are a negative certain equivalent for both transactions.

sections.text: It is often difficult to assess the utility function of the DM, and therefore sensitivity analysis is an instructive method to understand the impact of the risk problem on the optimal strategy and CE. sections.heading: 5 THE VALUE OF PERFECT HEDGING
sections.text: The value of perfect hedging (VoPH), previously reviewed in Section 2.4, is a compelling new technique for assessing the decision situation. It supports a proactive DM in assessing the value of other transactions that are relevant to the current decision situation and can offset "risks" from the existing distribution of value creation. Although the VoPH is a useful concept, the calculation can be extremely challenging. By Lemma 4, Note that finding the perfect hedge and the VoPH entails solving a difficult nonlinear optimization problem, since the CEPH is a nonlinear function of hedging. Seyller [2008] employs an exhaustive search method by sampling several possible values of perfect hedging. The topic in this paper is to avoid a reassessment of the decision situation for calculations; through the theorems in this section we show that there is a very efficient way to calculate the VoPH using partial derivative information.

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: Sensitivity analysis is critical to decision analysis, helping the DM to consider the value of further information gathering and the benefits of greater parameter precision. In this paper, we presented three sensitivity analysis methods that can be easily applied within decision-making circuits and do not require a re-evaluation of the decision situation, making them easily accessible to potentially major decision-making problems. We showed how a DM should examine the impact of switching to a different policy or more flexible solution, as well as find agreements that can effectively safeguard its current portfolio. We showed that DMs can draw valuable insights from the partially derived information available in decision-making circuits.
